extendedMetadata.name: Objective
extendedMetadata.value: LO: 19.2: How did the growth of American cities affect social, cultural, and political life?

subject: US History
metadata.bookAuthor: H. W. Brands; T. H. Breen; R. Hal Williams; Ariela J. Gros
metadata.title: FA Analyze 19 05

config.question: How did industrialization and urbanization impact family life?

choices.content: Unlike farm life, where family members worked together, urban working families separated at dawn and were not reunited until dark.
The urban workplace was strictly limited to male heads of households.
Young children of urban workers often went to school instead of working in factories or sweatshops.
Urban working families often worked as a unit, creating their products within their own homes or tenements.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Late-nineteenth-century working-class families, like that of the young Polish girl that Harriet Vittum saw, often lived in complex household units—taking in relatives and boarders to pay the rent. As many as one-third of all households contained people who were not members of the immediate family. See L.O. 19.2 How did the growth of American cities affect social, cultural, and political life?
